results.title: Going, going, still here!
results.creator_credit: ACMI Digital Storytelling, Garry Hammer and ACMI
results.brief_description:
Garry Hammer and his family battle the Gippsland bushfires to save their home.
Garry’s story is a personal account of the fire front that swept through his property, creating its own weather, a life-threatening yet positive force that ultimately gave him a new perspective on his life and his relationship with his son.
This Digital Storytelling project was created in partnership with Arts Victoria and Latrobe City.
results.creator_credit_for_label: ACMI Digital Storytelling, Garry Hammer and ACMI

results.title: Going to the dogs (A)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian mosaic”.
Aboriginal Australians have a special bond with their dogs, partly due to their traditional role in assisting in the hunt, and partly because they are part of the Dreamtime and related ceremonies. The Aborigines are therefore extremely reluctant to put down unhealthy dogs, so when it was discovered that a simple injection of a new drug restored their health, and with it, the health of the Aborigines themselves, particularly in relation to skin diseases and stomach upsets, the solution was welcomed by black communities and white authorities alike.

results.title: Going to school in Australia
results.creator_credit: Austarama Television, Nicholas and Kenneth Mott
results.brief_description: A film designed to instruct immigrants to Australia on the nature of the Australian and especially the Victorian education systems. Two representatives in the field of migrant education are questioned about how parents may proceed to enrol their children at school, the different kinds of schools in the Australian system, their various functions and facilities, adult education and several other facets of the education system. Narrated by Barry McQueen.

results.title: Going to Nan & Pop's Farm
results.creator_credit: Candice Jones and ACMI Digital Storytelling
results.brief_description: Produced in partnership with Arts Access and supported by the Department of Human Services and the Deafness Foundation for the ACMI Digital Storytelling Workshop ‘Telling Tales’. Candice recounts the fond memories of visiting her grandparents’ flower farm. This story is told with animated illustrations, photographs and video footage.

results.title: Going to my mum's house
results.creator_credit: Debbie Lissek and ACMI Digital Storytelling
results.brief_description: Produced in partnership with Arts Access and supported by the Department of Human Services and the Deafness Foundation for the ACMI Digital Storytelling Workshop ‘Telling Tales’. Debbie lives in a hostel, but spends weekends at her mum’s house. In this story, Debbie gives an outline of the activities she and her mum routinely enjoy on the weekends.

results.title: Going to blazes
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Look at Life”.
A survey of fire-fighting services in Britain. Over 35,000 fire-fighters, some full-time, some part-time keep constant watch for outbreaks of fire in town or country. Shows something of life on and off duty with units of the Glasgow and London fire services; visits a Fire Research Station where experts study the cause and effect of fire. Narrated by Tim Turner.
results.description:

results.title: Going through customs
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Rolly Productions and Rolly Desmarais
results.brief_description: Every day, streams of people, goods and commodities of all descriptions come into Canada at border crossings along the 6 500 km Canada-U.S. border, and via airports and seaports. Keeping the traffic moving expeditiously, at the same time ensuring that Canadian government regulations concerning immigration, customs and excise, health, and agriculture are observed, is the job of the Customs Officer. This is a colorful, coast-to-coast look at the variety that enters into his day.
results.creator_credit_for_label: ONF | NFB, Rolly Productions and Rolly Desmarais
results.description: Every day, streams of people, goods and commodities of all descriptions come into Canada at border crossings along the 6 500 km Canada-U.S. border, and via airports and seaports. This is a colorful, coast-to-coast look at the variety that enters into his day.

results.title: Going the distance
results.creator_credit: Jacques Bobet, Robert Verrall, ONF | NFB and Paul Cowan
results.brief_description: The official film of the XI Commonwealth Games held in Edmonton, Canada, in August 1978. An international sports event occurring every four years, the games draw hundreds of athletes from the many nations of the Commonwealth. Eight athletes from four continents were selected to illustrate the nature of individual effort. They were filmed in their home countries before the Games, and in competition in Edmonton, Canada.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jacques Bobet, Robert Verrall, ONF | NFB and Paul Cowan

results.title: Going Solo
results.brief_description:
Through life experiences such as divorce, bereavement or never meeting the right soulmate we may find ourselves fifty plus and living on our own. For some in this situation a new partner is not what they crave, just the supportive friendship of those who understand.

Based on a series of interviews conducted with members of a Catholic Women’s solo group, this 36 min amateur documentary is a first time effort for the filmmaker and although the production values are at times questionable - the heart and soul of the women interviewed shine through making this a warm, often funny and inspirational account of life for a growing number of people in our community.
results.description:
Through life experiences such as divorce, bereavement or never meeting the right soulmate we may find ourselves fifty plus and living on our own. For some in this situation a new partner is not what they crave, just the supportive friendship of those who understand.

Based on a series of interviews conducted with members of a Catholic Women’s solo group, this 36 min amateur documentary is a first time effort for the filmmaker and although the production values are at times questionable - the heart and soul of the women interviewed shine through making this a warm, often funny and inspirational account of life for a growing number of people in our community.
